In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the implementation of the function in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    if typeof(dt) == Date
        throw(ArgumentError("Provided argument must be a DateTime type"))
    end
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end
```
This function `timezone_bumper` accepts a `DateTime` and an optional parameter `bump`. If no value is provided, it defaults to 3 hours. The function first checks if the input argument is of type `Date`, in which case it throws an error. Otherwise, it adds the bumped time to the DateTime object and returns this new DateTime.

Here's how you can use it:

```julia
julia> dt = now()
2022-03-14T18:56:37

julia> timezone_bumper(dt)
2022-03-14T21:56:37
```
